  • Distance

Distance¶

caer.distance.distance(bw, metric='euclidean2')[source]¶
Computes the distance transform of image bw::

dmap[i,j] = min_{i’, j’} { (i-i’)**2 + (j-j’)**2 | !bw[i’, j’] }

That is, at each point, compute the distance to the background. If there is no background, then a very high value will be returned in all pixels (this is a sort of infinity).

bwndarray

If boolean, False will denote the background and True the foreground. If not boolean, this will be interpreted as bw != 0 (this way you can use labeled images without any problems).

metricstr, optional

one of ‘euclidean2’ (default) or ‘euclidean’

dmapndarray

distance map

For 2-D images, the following algorithm is used: Felzenszwalb P, Huttenlocher D. Distance transforms of sampled functions. Cornell Computing and Information. 2004. Available at: http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.88.1647&rep=rep1&type=pdf. For n-D images (with n > 2), a slower hand-craft method is used.
